item.title: The UAE Central Bank has introduced raised marks on certain currency notes to assist individuals with visual impairments
item.description:
The Central Bank of the United Arab Emirates has introduced new AED1,000, AED20, and AED10 banknotes featuring raised tactile marks designed to assist people with visual impairments, according to the Emirates News Agency, WAM. These new banknotes incorporate tactile elements created using the intaglio printing method on their widths. The AED1,000 note now includes two sets of four horizontal lines, evenly spaced, on both the left and right edges. item.title: India no longer accepts high denomination notes in the current series
item.description:
India’s Reserve Bank (RBI) has decided to discontinue the use of 500 and 1,000 rupee notes. These notes ceased to be legal tender as of November 9, 2016. Consequently, ATMs and other cash transaction machines were shut down on November 9 and 10. However, bank branches and government treasuries remained open on November 10. This move was prompted by the difficulty in differentiating real banknotes from counterfeit ones. The surge in fake currency was negatively impacting the Indian economy...
